conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on both the block and the plank to determine the condition for F_1.
The block is subject to three forces: applied vertical force F_2, gravitational force mg, and frictional force f.
The frictional force f acts horizontally and opposes the motion of the block, acting downward when the block starts moving upward.
The maximum static frictional force is given by f_max = μN, where N is the normal force exerted by the plank on the block.
Normal force N is equal to the component of the gravitational force perpendicular to the plank.
Normal force N can be found using the geometry of the plank and the block, assumed as N = mg cos θ.
Maximum static frictional force is f_max = μ mg cos θ.
For the block to start moving upward, F_2 must be greater than mg, thus F_2 > 8.0 N.
For the plank to move upward, horizontal force F_1 must overcome the frictional force f, thus F_1 > μ mg cos θ.
Minimum value of F_1 is determined by the condition that the block starts moving, thus F_1 > μ mg.
Given μ = 0.20, m = 0.80 kg, and g = 10 m/s², F_1 > 1.6 N.
Condition that F_1 must satisfy for the plank to move upward is F_1 > 1.6 N.
